description.narrative: Sustainable forest management to secure multiple benefits in Pakistans high conservation value forests

activity-description.narrative: Conserve biodiversity, mitigate climate change and secure forest ecosystem services

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: Indicator 1.1: Number of forest management plan protocols/guidelines for mainstreaming ecosystem, climate risk mitigation and biodiversity considerations into forest management in Pakistan Indicator 1.2: Number of forest monitoring protocols to assess effectiveness of adoption for SFM in forestlands Indicator 1.3: Number of forest community members and private forest owners undergone technical and skills training and development in sustainable forest management Indicator 1.4: Number of Baseline assessment report on current unsustainable and sustainable resource use practices, state and/or condition of resources and baseline of key indicator species Indicator 1.5: Number of forest resource use conflicts effective resolved Indicator 1.6: Number of comprehensive recommendations for scaling-up and replication of sustainable forest management approaches emanating from the project sites Indicator 1.7: Number of forest monitoring protocols to assess effectiveness of adoption for SFM in forestlands Indicator 2.1: Hectares of high biodiversity conservation value forests identified, designated and effectively managed for biodiversity and climate mitigation Indicator 2.2: Population trends of key indicator species of Ovis vignei, Axis porcinus, Pucrasia macrolop, Platanista gangetica minor stable or increasing Indicator 2.3: Extent of forest ecosystem covered under a model for Community Managed Conservation in High Value Coniferous Forests with high potential for replication established Indicator 2.4: Percentage of households reporting increased incomes in community managed conservation areas from forest and non forest resources. Indicator 2.5: Number of forest dependent community members and private forest owners trained in conservation based sustainable resources Indicator 2.6: Number of community members completed standardized training programme encompassing i) community organizational skills, ii) community-based SFM, iii) participatory monitoring, iv) biodiversity-frien

comment.narrative: Baseline 1.1: 0 (Number of forest management plan protocols/guidelines for mainstreaming ecosystem, climate risk mitigation and biodiversity considerations into forest management in Pakistan) Baseline 1.2: 0 (Number of forest landscapes completed, forest inventory and maps in support of sustainable forest management) Baseline 1.3: 0 (Number of forest community members and private forest owners undergone technical and skills training and development in sustainable forest management ) Baseline 1.4: 0 ( Number of Baseline assessment report on current unsustainable and sustainable resource use practices, state and/or condition of resources and baseline of key indicator species) Baseline 1.5: 0 (Number of forest resource use conflicts effective resolved) Baseline 1.6: 0 Baseline 1.7: 0 Baseline 2.1: 0 (Hectares of high biodiversity conservation value forests identified, designated and effectively managed for biodiversity and climate mitigation) Baseline 2.2: 345, 1650, 200 & 25(Population trends of key indicator species of Ovisvigneipunjabensis, Axis porcinus, Pucrasiamacrolop, Platanistagangetica minor stable or increasing) Baseline 2.3: 0 (Extent of forest ecosystem covered under a model for Community Managed Conservation in High Value Coniferous Forests with high potential for replication established) Baseline 2.4: 0 Baseline 2.5: 0 Baseline 2.6: 0 Baseline 3.1: 0 (Number of hectares of Sub-tropical broadleaved evergreen thorny forests and Western Himalayan Temperate Coniferous forests rehabilitated) Baseline 3.2: 0 (Number of hectares of riverine forest reforested with native species) Baseline 3.3: 0 Baseline 3.4: 0 (Number of Carbon stock assessments and coefficients for key forest types in Pakistan developed and monitored) Baseline 3.2.2: 0 Baseline 3.4: 0

1.1: 1 [One survey on inventory of ecological services in Siren and Kaghan] 1.2: 3 [Provincial/district (KPK, Sindh, and Punjab) level forest entities will be employing guidelines/ management plants] 1.3: 4 [Draft forest management plans developed (2 in KPK, 2 for Punjab is covering under 1.2 and 2 in Sindh)] 1.4: 4 [Assessment reports (one for each landscape in KPK and Punjab) on unsustainable resource practices and key indicators species] 1.5: 2 [Monitoring protocols, one each for Sindh and KPK provinces] 1.6: 1 [One assessment report on identification and resolution of conflicts (one for Sindh, one for Punjab)] 1.6: 0 [Target is fixed for last year of the project] 2.1: 4000 [At least 4000 ha of Western Himalayan Conifer forests , 1000 ha of sub tropical evergreen thorny forests and 1500 ha of riverine forests] 2.2: 3000 hectares 2.3. 200 [100 persons in KPK, 50 in Sindh and 50 in Punjab] 2.4: 6 3.1: 1000 [ha of sub tropical broad leafed evergreen thorny forests and 1000 ha of Western Himalayan Temperate Coniferous forests] 3.2: 1000 [ha in Sindh] 3.3: 1 [One study for documenting best practices] 3.4.a: 1 [One set of baseline assessment completed]

1.1: 1 [Study on documenting ecological services available to the people living in and near the forests has been conducted for Kaghan in KPK and Kot-Dhingano in Sindh]. 1.2: 3 [Provincial forest departments in KPK, Sindh and Punjab are effectively applying the considerations for biodiversity conservation, climate mitigation and ensuring lasting ecosystem services for the communities’ use]. 1.3: 0 [Process of developing forest management plans in all the three provinces have been initiated in KPK, Punjab and Sindh. These are not yet finalized and are under consideration again in 2020]. 1.4: [Assessment studies on listing the resources usage practices and key indicator species have been conducted]. 1.5: 1 [Work for developing the monitoring protocol in KPK is under way because 8 workshops were held towards developing the monitoring protocols in order to reflect also the forest officials view points about the protocols to be developed]. 1.6: 3 [Assessment on identification and resolution of conflict have conducted in Sindh, Punjab and KPK]. 1.8: 0 [Target is fixed for last year of the project] 2.1: 7915 [Hectares land of HCVA identified in sub-tropical evergreen thorny forests (2280 hectares in Diljaba forests, 4339 hectares in Ara and 1296 hectares in Pareera forests)]. 2.2: 14 [VDCs have been organized 7 each in Kaghan and Siren Forests Divisions]. 2.3: [No targets achieved in 2019]. 2.4: 6 [Training sessions were conducted in Punjab to sensitize the community members and training total 285 persons (40 female and 245 male)]. 3.1: 1553 [(Hectares in KPK) and (623 hectares in Punjab) were regenerated]. 3.2: 2024 hectares in Sindh (1012 in Sukkur, 688 in Lakhat and 324 in Kot Dhingano) were regenerated. 3.3: 0 [No target achieved in 2019]. 3.4a: 1 [One set of baseline assessment completed]. 3.4b: 0 [Target not achieved in 2019].

1.1: 7 [Seven Draft Management Plans: 2 in KPK, 2 in Sindh and 3 in Punjab] 1.2: 2 [Two GPS based monitoring system in KPK and one national park in Punjab] 1.3: 200 1.4: 7 [One report on unsustainable & sustainable resource use practices from each province] 1.5: 3 1.6: 5 [Study on documenting best practices adopted by SFM] 1.7: No target set for 2021 2.1: 26459 hectares [9,000 ha in KPK, 7459 ha in Punjab and 10, 000 ha in Sindh] 2.2: 3[ one wildlife survey in each of three provinces] 2.3. 8000 ha 2.4: 1 2.5: 100 2.6: No target set for 2021 3.1: 3250 [500 ha in Punjab, and 1750 ha in KPK and 1000 ha of Subtropical dry conifer forests] 3.2: 1500 [ha in Sindh] 3.3: 5 [Atleast 5 best practice notes documents] 3.4: No target planned for 2020 3.5: No target planned for 2020

1.1: 3 [Management plans in Punjab have been prepared, while one plan in Sindh and two in KPK are underway] 1.2 : 0 [Contracts for the establishment GPS based monitoring system in KPK and Punjab have been awarded to private firm selected through a thorough competitive process] 1.3: 0 [trainings have not been conducted till writing of this report because of COVID-19] 1.4 07 [Baseline studies for variety of resources and key indicators species have been conducted in the previous years. However, during the year, a study on the unsustainable practices has been conducted in Siren landscape of the project] 1.5: 7 [Three conflicts’ assessments were made: 7 conflicts were identified in the scrubs landscape, 1 in the riverine and 12 in the western Himalayan Coniferous landscape in KPK] 1.6: 03 [Protected areas act 2020 finalized in Punjab, which is suggested to be replicated in other parts of the country as well; 2. Rules for the protected areas were finalized; and 3. Punjab Forest Policy was also finalized] 1.7: NA 2.1: 56880 ha [8684 hectares in Punjab, 5345 hectares land in Sindh18753 in KP have been declared as high value conservation] 2.2: 3 [three surveys were conducted; one in each province.] 2.3: 9000 ha[4000 hectares in upper Siran while 5000 hectares in Kaghan are under communities managed areas where the SFM works with organized communities.] 2.4:1 [One socio-economic assessment has been carried at the landscapes in KPK to assess impacts of SFM interventions] 2.5 75 [No training has been arranged in Punjab during the year due to COVID-19] 2.6: NA 3.1: 14532 [11476 hectares land in Punjab while 3056 hectares in KPK have been regenerated. (Increase in target at Punjab is because of the mutual arrangements with the TBTTP initiative in the country)] 3.2: 700 ha [land regenerated] 3.3: 3 [three best practices documented] 3.4: NA 3.5: NA

1.1: 7 [Seven Draft Management Plans: 2 in KPK, 2 in Sindh and 3 in Punjab] 1.2: 2 [Two GPS based monitoring system in KPK and one national park in Punjab] 1.3: 200 1.4: 7 [One report on unsustainable & sustainable resource use practices from each province] 1.5: 3 1.6: 5 [Study on documenting best practices adopted by SFM] 1.7: 2 monitoring protocols (1 in KPK and 1 in Sindh) 2.1: 26459 hectares [9,000 ha in KPK, 7459 ha in Punjab and 10, 000 ha in Sindh] 2.2: 3[ one wildlife survey in each of three provinces] 2.3. 8000 ha 2.4: 20% of which at least 30% of beneficiaries are women (One livelihood assessment of the SFM beneficiaries) 2.5: 100 2.6: At least 200, of which at least 10% would be women] 3.1: 3250 [500 ha in Punjab, and 1750 ha in KPK and 1000 ha of Subtropical dry conifer forests] 3.2: 1500 [ha in Sindh] 3.3: 5 [Atleast 5 best practice notes documents] 3.4: Target not set for 2021 3.5: Target not set for 2021

1.1: 7 [Targeted 7 management plans have been prepared accordingly]. 1.2: 2 [2 GPS based monitoring systems, one KPK and one in Punjab have been established] 1.3: NA 1.4: 0 1.5: 0 1.6: 2 [2 Feasibility studies have been conducted in KPK] 1.7: 1 [One MIS system has developed and operational is Sindh, while one MIS system is being developed in KPK]. 2.1: 26459 hectares [i. Maintained Hog Deer enclosure and Wetlands in landscapes through Negahbans; ii. 2 forest rest were renovated; iii. Ungulate breeding center is being established in Chakwal; iv. One partridge breeding center has been established in Chakwal; v. High value conservations forests (HVCFs) plans were finalized for Siran and Kaghan; vi. Manual for partridges breeding has been developed in KPK.] 2.2: 2 [One wildlife study has been conducted in Punjab and Study on Grey Langur conducted in KPK] 2.3: 8000 ha [The area has been covered through: i. One Pellet Machine has been procured in Punjab; ii. While one bracket has purchased in KPK] 2.4: 20% of which at least 30% of beneficiaries are women (One livelihood assessment of the SFM beneficiaries) [i. 9000 fruits plants for diversification of means of income distributed among local communities’ members of Sukkur and Kot Dhingano Lakhat Riverine Forest Landscape; ii. A vocational training centre for women has been established in Kaghan; iii. 8 organic products have identified for selling by the local communities in Siran and Kaghan; iv. Historical Muro track has been developed for promoting ecotourism]. 2.5: NA 2.6: [SFM carried out a training for 30 forest officers about using the Ten Billion Tree Tsunami Plantation (TBTTP) monitoring platform and 6 trainings for communities’ members were held in KPK]. 3.1: 2787 ha land regenerated in KPK through collaboration with TBTTP 3.2: 77 ha land regenerated because of no flood this year in Sindh 3.3: 3 [i. Parerra and Ara Reserve Forests were declared and inaugurated nature reserves; ii. Chinji National Park was inaugurated; iii. GPS system is established in scrubs and its functioning is awaiting to get frequency from PTA]. 3.4: NA 3.5: NA
